articles.title: Predictions
articles.summary: This document outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's events for January and February, including general meetings featuring talks on Copernicus's influence and the Moonwatch program, along with multiple indoor and outdoor star parties. It also lists Board of Directors meetings and concludes with humorous club quotes and contact information for the President and Editor.

articles.title: Catherine the Great
articles.summary: Catherine Ann Constance Pinheiro, born in Los Gatos in 1958, is a technical illustrator at Intel with aspirations of becoming a freelance artist. She discovered astronomy through a club membership for her 18th birthday and now serves as the club's secretary, enjoying the social and observational aspects of the hobby while not favoring its mathematical or technical details. She is currently making a telescope and looking for her "Camelot."

articles.title: Blurbs
articles.summary: This bulletin is late due to holidays and the editor's illness, with no 'Comet Comments' this month due to a lack of new discoveries or bright northern comets. An attempted asteroidal occultation of SAO114159 by (18) Melpomene yielded early reports of multiple objects, prompting a call for more observers. Other news includes new AANC officers, a Foothill College course on cosmic evolution, and a casual report from a recent board meeting.

articles.title: History
articles.summary: This article recounts the December 2 star party at Sanborn, highlighting several 'traumatic' events including the absence of Jack Zeiders for his birthday surprise, extreme cold weather, and the unexpected arrival of numerous West Valley College astronomy students. Amidst a loud music contest that annoyed attendees, the focus shifted to entertaining the college students, with several members braving the cold for the event.

articles.title: General Meeting of December 9
articles.summary: The December 9 general meeting featured an announcement regarding a now-canceled February eclipse flight. The program included Gerry Rattley presenting on Messier objects for an upcoming marathon and Richard Hansen showcasing astronomy-related postcards. The meeting concluded with a birthday celebration for several members.

articles.title: Rattley Rattles
articles.summary: This article serves as a prelude to an upcoming two-part Messier catalogue/checklist for the Messier Marathon, which is three months away. It outlines a 13-zone sky division to aid observers, details the 110 Messier objects included in the catalogue (noting exceptions for viewing and AANC award requirements), and provides important registration information. Additionally, it lists useful alignment stars with 1980 coordinates for setting sidereal time.

articles.title: RATTLEY RATTLES ON . . . (continuation)
articles.summary: This article details a multi-night Messier Marathon event, providing participants with guidance on note-taking for observation requirements and a bibliography of recommended books for Messier studies. It outlines participation rules, emphasizing self-discovery of objects, and specifies the dates (late March/early April), location (Don Machholz's site on Loma Prieta Mt.), and directions for the event.

articles.title: Christmas, Astronomically Speaking.....
articles.summary: On December 16th, an astronomy club hosted a festive Christmas gathering at the Red Cross, featuring Santa and his Elf distributing presents and lighthearted interactions. Following the holiday merriment, attendees engaged in typical indoor star party activities, including unsuccessful carol singing and a dedicated mirror-polishing workshop. The report also touches on general club discussions and concludes with classified advertisements for astronomical equipment.

articles.title: Reply to the President
articles.summary: This article humorously describes the "Limburger Cheese Photometer," a fictional astronomical instrument whose principle relies on limburger cheese decomposition to produce vapors that cause observers to pass out, with the number of unconscious observers correlating to stellar magnitude. Presented as a satirical response to a president, the piece parodies technical descriptions, scientific jargon, and the pursuit of federal grants in group astronomy.

articles.title: Question of the Month: "What was the Star of Bethlehem?"
articles.summary: This article presents a collection of diverse, often humorous, and speculative responses to the 'Question of the Month: What was the Star of Bethlehem?'. Responses range from astronomical theories like planetary conjunctions in Leo or a supernova, to more whimsical, religious, or purely imaginative interpretations. It highlights the varied perspectives on this historical and astronomical mystery.

articles.title: Great Red Spot On Meridian PST
articles.summary: This article provides a detailed schedule for observing Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) on the meridian in Pacific Standard Time throughout January, coinciding with Jupiter's opposition on January 21st. It encourages amateur astronomers to use telescopes to look for the GRS, offering tips on power and waiting for good seeing conditions. The information is geared towards observers, originating from Calico Observatory.
